comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Looks like it might be Hunter's bar in Ballyvoy now. maps.google.ie/maps?q=fairhead+antrim&hl=en&ll=55...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Equally, though, it might not. One of these houses looks pretty much like another: maps.google.ie/maps?q=fairhead+antrim&hl=en&ll=55...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tj_q8] In rural areas one needed 7 rooms to be classed as an hotel whereas the requirement was much higher in an urban setting.  Very interesting shot and obviously well staged.  The wee dram looks more like stout or porter rather than whiskey or spirits and the bottle is being drained to the last.  My grandmother died the Christmas before I was born and my family who were teetotallers had the obligatory barrel of stout for the wake.  After the funeral my maiden aunt filled out three pint glasses of stale stout for the drivers of the hearse and horse carriages for the mourners and stood over the poor men until they had emptied the last drop:-((  My father had to hide lest she see him laughing and give him a thick ear!  This reminds me of the story!!!

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I'd go with the Hunters - the setting looks right and it would be more likely to be on the main road. It's obviously had a bit of work/damage done to it in the meantime though!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] I'm not so sure. The 1904 OS map has a post office where those trees are. It also has the pub facing west whereas this house looks like it's facing south(ish).
Edit: Though google maps has the sun coming in at much the same angle as the image above.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,715566,940668,7,8 It'd be the long thin one opposite the pound. Not very convincing, really, is it?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] That OS link isn't working for me for some reason. I'm looking at the other side of this house as a possibility. It would have been facing the road at the time and the orientation looks about right.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] I saw that one (I've google streetveiwed the entire Torr, Fairhead and Murlough roads) but I think the chimneys are too narrow.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I'm wondering if it might be up round Ballycastle with a view of Fairhead instead.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Here's an Isabella McLaughlin in the 1901 census who is a head of household (albeit farmer rather than hotelier - could be a seasonal thing). I can't find where Ballyscullion or Culnafay might be though. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1901/Antrim/Ballyscu... There's a Ballyscullion Road near Bellaghy which wouldn't be the right area at all.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The thing is though, people don't give up a license without a fight in this country, so it's quite likely it's still a pub.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Here's Culnafay: maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,700519,897293,6,8. You could be on to something; There's nothing to stop you calling your hotel whatever you like.

comment.author: 95431395@N05
comment._content: This is now Hunter's Bar in Ballyvoy. The Torr Road starts here and runs up between the white wall and the trees on the left.
